docs.abstract: Editorial offers advice to Chinese government, which is said to be looking for public relations firm to shore up its image before 2008 Olympic Games; says it can stop arresting dissidents, stop spreading lies about Dalai Lama and instead open dialogue about freedoms for Tibet; suggests it stop being enabler to Sudan in Darfur genocide and start delivering on pledge to respect human rights; says it is typical of authoritarian regimes to presume that huge protests such as those accompanying Olympic torch journey are provocations instigated by nefarious foes; says China has not proven itself worthy to be host to Games and has only itself to blame

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.snippet: In the spirit of the Olympic ideals, we are prepared to help China  free of charge. Here’s what you do: Stop arresting dissidents.
docs.lead_paragraph: After facing major protests in London and Paris as the Olympic torch made stops on its journey to Beijing, the Chinese government is said to be looking for a public relations firm to patch up China's image before the 2008 Games in August. In the spirit of the Olympic ideals, we are prepared to help China -- free of charge. Here's what you do: Stop arresting dissidents. Stop spreading lies about the Dalai Lama, and start talking to him about greater religious and cultural freedoms for Tibet. Stop being an enabler to Sudan in its genocide in Darfur. In other words, start delivering on the pledge you made to the International Olympic Committee to respect human rights -- which, by the way, include the freedom of expression and the freedom of assembly.

docs.abstract: Olympic torch is set to make its only United States appearance along increasingly tense international tour en route to Beijing; it will star in relay along San Francisco's waterfront, involving 79 runners and scores of law enforcement officials, although precise route remains in flux; city is faced with potential of protests by those upset with China's human rights record and crackdown on Tibet; city has established extra security measures, including calling in state and federal agencies and officers from nearby cities to help patrol relay route; map; photo (M)

headline.main: As Torch Reaches San Francisco, It Runs for Cover Before Its Run

docs.snippet: The Olympic torch extravaganza could become a civic migraine in the face of potential protests against China.

byline.original: By JESSE McKINLEY; Jim Yardley contributed reporting from Beijing and Carolyn Marshall and Karen Crouse from San Francisco

docs.lead_paragraph: The Olympic torch arrived at the airport here from Paris in the wee hours Tuesday morning, exited out a side door and was escorted by motorcade to a downtown hotel. There it took a well-deserved break in a room complete with cable TV, room service and views of the city's popular Union Square shopping district. ''It has very comfortable accommodations,'' said Mike McCarron, an airport spokesman, who said the flame -- ensconced in a handsome brass lantern and accompanied by several backup flames -- was ''treated similar to a head of state.''

docs.abstract: British Prime Min Gordon Brown says he will not attend opening ceremony of Beijing Olympic Games this summer but will attend closing ceremony (M)

headline.main: British Leader Says He Won't Attend Opening Ceremony of Beijing Olympics

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Gordon Brown has been under intense political pressure over whether he would attend the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics this summer.
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Gordon Brown said Wednesday that he would not attend the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympic Games this summer. The prime minister has been under intense political pressure over the issue. Asked about it repeatedly, he has until now refused to rule out going, and even seemed to imply that he did plan to go.

docs.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses protests over China's human rights record, and whether 2008 Olympic torch relay will be targeted by activists in advance of Beijing Games; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For this torch relay ritual that began in 1936, any tidy balance between protest and disorder may no longer be possible.
docs.lead_paragraph: The turmoil in the streets of San Francisco on Wednesday -- ominous dark-clad SWAT team members protecting single runners carrying the Olympic torch through a gantlet of protesters -- has been coming for a long time. It began on that July day in 2001 when the International Olympic Committee voted to make Beijing the host of the 2008 Summer Games. In those simpler hours before 9/11, that vote seemed like an idealistic notion, acknowledging the economic progress of China, hands across the sea.

docs.abstract: Profile of distance runner Ryan Hall, winner of US Olympic marathon trials who is preparing for 2008 Games; photo (M)

headline.main: Only 26 Miles to Go on Hall's Long Road to Beijing

docs.snippet: The 25-year-old winner of the United States Olympic marathon trials is ready for the real thing: an Olympic medal in Beijing.
docs.lead_paragraph: Like so many young athletes, Ryan Hall envisioned running for his country. Only, his Olympic dream came complete with props and a soundtrack. He played the Olympic theme song nonstop as a teenager in the Southern California town of Bear Lake, and now has the music on his iPod. His wife, Sara, made an Olympic torch lamp for him when they were at Stanford. Hall put that in his Olympic room in their house, where he also tacked his American flag to the wall.

docs.abstract: International Olympic Committee president Jacques Rogge calls on Beijing to honor its pledges to improve human rights and give foreign journalists unfettered access; condemns protesters who have dogged torch relay in several countries; China rejects Bogge's remarks, accusing IOC of meddling; photo (M)

headline.main: Top Olympic Official Calls Protests a 'Crisis' and Chides China on Rights Policies

docs.snippet: The president of the Olympic committee called on the authorities in Beijing to improve human rights.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Warren Hoge and Sarah Wheaton contributed reporting from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: China faced rare criticism of its human rights record from the head of the International Olympics Committee on Thursday, even as calls for a boycott of the opening ceremony of the Games grew louder in Europe and the United States. The president of the Olympic committee, Jacques Rogge, called on the authorities in Beijing to respect their ''moral engagement'' to improve human rights in the months leading up to the Games and to provide the news media with greater access to the country. He also described the protests that have dogged the international Olympics torch relay as a ''crisis'' for the organization.

docs.abstract: Vembar K Ranganathan letter urges Pres Bush not to attend opening ceremonies of Beijing Olympics; says that serving as host for Olympics is honor, and bestowing this on country with scant regard for basic human rights has stirred protests by global citizens (April 9 editorial)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     ''The Torch and Freedom'' (editorial, April 9) is right  with its sage advice that China does not need a public relations firm, but simply needs to stop imprisoning dissidents.
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Torch and Freedom'' (editorial, April 9) is right with its sage advice that China does not need a public relations firm, but simply needs to stop imprisoning dissidents.

docs.abstract: Already tarnished Beijing Olympics have become political and well as athletic spectacle; extent to which politics will intrude on Games and whether international pressure on China will improve or worsen its policies on Tibet, Darfur and other delicate issues have become major concerns for diplomats, athletes and commercial sponsors of Olympics; protests around Games have created uncomfortable moral dilemma for West, which wants to promote freedom but does not want to provoke backlash; photo (M)

headline.main: For the West, Many Tough Calls on China

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.snippet: The intrusion of politics into the 2008 Olympic Games to be hosted by China has become a major worry for diplomats, athletes and the event’s commercial sponsors.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER; Jim Yardley contributed reporting from Beijing, Alison Smale from Berlin, Katrin Bennhold from Paris and Katie Thomas from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Dalai Lama begins a contentious two-week visit to the United States and the Olympic torch continues its tortuous journey across six continents toward Beijing, the 2008 Games, already tarnished, have become a political as well as an athletic spectacle, with vying theories of human rights and how best to promote them. Groups devoted to causes as diverse as press freedom, Falun Gong, Tibet and autonomy for Uighur Muslims in China's far west have used the Games as leverage to highlight issues that had been relegated to advocacy chat rooms during most of China's long economic boom.

docs.abstract: Photos of protesters against Beijing Olympics with signs showing five interlocking rings of Olympic logo
docs.snippet: Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the French founder of the modern Olympic Games, probably didn't have this in mind when he came up with a logo of five interlocking rings in 1913, a logo that was then incorporated into the Olympic flag in 1920. The rings st
docs.lead_paragraph: Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the French founder of the modern Olympic Games, probably didn't have this in mind when he came up with a logo of five interlocking rings in 1913, a logo that was then incorporated into the Olympic flag in 1920. The rings stand for the five continents (North and South America share a ring, and Antarctica lacks eligible bipeds). But how tempting those adaptable rings are when it comes to protest, particularly against China, host of the 2008 Games. Creative alterations of the rings have highlighted grievances as the Olympic torch has made its way from city to city in the last couple of weeks. Many of the doctored-logo signs call for a free Tibet. Some call for an end to the Chinese role as an enabler to Sudan in the genocide in Darfur, and at least one calls for the independence of the Uighurs, a Muslim minority in western China.

docs.abstract: Grass-roots Tibet support groups are embarking on public relations plan to raise awareness as Beijing Olympics approaches, sensing opportunity to have their voices heard; are pulling off successful publicity coup, forcing China to go on defensive rather than celebrate glow of coming games; focus has shifted from athletics in Beijing to crackdown on Tibet (M)

headline.main: Tibet Backers Show China Value of P.R.

docs.snippet: With the Olympics in mind, China has been exploring American-style public relations approaches.
docs.lead_paragraph: Soon after China was awarded the Olympic Games seven years ago, a series of public relations strategy sessions were held. But it wasn't the Chinese government holding the sessions: it was grass-roots Tibet support groups in the United States and abroad. The protesters quickly established a communications plan, focused their message and ran camps where they taught members interview skills and even rappelling -- as they showed off last week in hanging banners on the Golden Gate Bridge.
